results.title: The Afghan Military Was Built Over 20 Years. How Did It Collapse So Quickly?
results.abstract: The Taliban’s rapid advance has made clear that U.S. efforts to turn Afghanistan’s military into a robust, independent fighting force have failed, with its soldiers feeling abandoned by inept leaders.
results.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Sharif Hassan
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: Poverty, Disease, Customs: Why So Many Indonesian Children Die of Covid
results.abstract: The disease kills far more children in developing countries than in rich ones, and some factors make them especially vulnerable in Indonesia.

results.title: A Popular Comedy’s Return in France Exposes Growing Divides
results.abstract: After 12 years, a French spy spoof movie series featuring a clueless, racist and sexist hero re-emerges in a nation where laughter has become more complicated.

results.title: A Sicilian Town Sends an Omen of a Much Hotter Future
results.abstract: Floridia may have hit 124 degrees Fahrenheit this week, possibly the highest temperature ever recorded in Europe, offering Italy and the entire Mediterranean a preview of things to come.

multimedia.caption: The deserted Madonna del Carmine square on Friday in Floridia, Sicily. “Floridia is now the center of the world when it comes to the climate,” said its mayor, Marco Carianni.
multimedia.copyright: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times

results.title: Afghanistan’s Unraveling May Strike Another Blow to U.S. Credibility
results.abstract: Allies may understand the desire to give up on a failed project, but the retreat heightens the sense that America’s backing is no longer unbounded.

results.title: Latest U.K. Scandals Show a System Rife With Insider Ties
results.abstract: For years, Britain relied on an informal code of gentlemen’s agreements to help prevent influence-peddling and cronyism in politics. Some say that no longer works.

results.title: As the Taliban Advance in Afghanistan, Pressure on Pakistan Grows
results.abstract: The United States and others want Pakistan to push harder for peace. But many Pakistanis see a Taliban victory as inevitable, and some are cheering for one.

results.abstract: Lale Gul’s autobiographical and sexually frank tale of a woman breaking with her conservative Muslim culture, and her strict parents, is a best seller in the Netherlands. “I’m done hiding,” she says.

results.title: An Afghan warlord who steadfastly resisted the Taliban surrendered. Others may follow his lead.
results.abstract: The surrender of Ismail Khan, the only warlord who posed a serious threat to the insurgents in the western region of the country, could be a sign that others may soon switch allegiances.

results.title: Three more major cities are under Taliban control, as the government’s forces near collapse.
results.abstract: With Lashkar Gah and Kandahar, the Taliban now effectively control southern Afghanistan. The western city of Herat is also in their hands.

results.title: Iran’s Health System ‘Beyond Disastrous’ from Covid Surge
results.abstract: The Delta variant of the coronavirus has overwhelmed the country, which has been reeling from the pandemic since it began, presenting a stark test for its new hard-line president.

results.title: Rare Mass Shooting in Britain Leaves 6 Dead, Including a Child
results.abstract: The killings in the southwestern city of Plymouth were not terrorism-related, the police said. It was the country’s first mass shooting since 2010.
results.byline: By Daniel Victor and Stephen Castle
